questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the vasomotor reversal of Dale?

options.label: A
options.text: Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulation of beta 1 followed by a block of beta 2

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of beta 1 receptor followed by a block of beta 2 receptor

options.label: D
options.text: Beta 2 stimulation by norepinephrine followed by beta 1 stimulation

questions.correct_answer: A. Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- There can’t be stimulation of Beta 1 or Beta 2 receptors initially because at high doses adrenaline has a high affinity for Alpha 1 receptors (as it causes a rise in BP). Later when the adrenaline is metabolized in some doses then its further action on Beta 2 receptors occurs. Therefore, other options B, C & D are not correct.

Extraedge:

Dale's phenomenon: At high concentrations epinephrine shows a biphasic response, that is an initial rise in BP due to stimulation of alpha1 followed by a fall in blood pressure due to stimulation of beta 2. Because at high concentrations epinephrine has an affinity for alpha receptors Vasomotor reversal of Dale: When an alpha blocker is given and then epinephrine is given then there is only a fall in blood pressure mediated by beta 2 stimulation.

questions.text: A patient with septic shock was in ICU and was started on norepinephrine. During the therapy onset of norepinephrine action correlates with:

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased renal perfusion and decrease urine output

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased MAP

Highyeild:

Norepinephrine Acts on α1 + α2 + β1 + β3 but no β2 action α1-vasoconstriction - Increases DBP. β1-increases heart rate and contractility - Increases SBP. This increases mean arterial pressure which causes a reflex vagal activity that decreases the heart rate leading to bradycardia. Mean arterial pressure is 2 DBP + SBP / 3 Increases peripheral resistance due to vasoconstriction (α 1 action) When given iv it reduces heart rate due to reflex bradycardia by vagal stimulation and this can be overcome by anti-vagal(anti-cholinergic) drugs like atropine So the response to the onset of norepinephrine action correlates with the increase in map To perfuse vital organs requires the maintenance of a minimum map of 60 mmHg. If the map drops below this point for an extended period, end-organ manifestations such as ischemia and infarction can occur.

questions.text: Hyperkalaemia immediate management is all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Magnesium The intravenous administration of 1 to 2 g MgSO4 reportedly is effective in preventing recurrent episodes of torsades de pointes, even if the serum Mg2+ concentration is normal.

Highyeild:

DRUGS GIVEN FOR HYPERKALEMIA Severe hyperkalemia requires emergent treatment directed at minimizing membrane depolarization, shifting K' into cells, and promoting K' loss. Administration of calcium gluconate decreases membrane excitability. The effect begins within minutes but is short-lived (30-60 min), and the dose can be repeated if no change in the electrocardiogram is seen after 5-10 min. Insulin causes K' to shift into cells and will temporarily lower the plasma K' concentration. Although glucose alone will stimulate insulin release from normal pancreatic beta cells, a more rapid response generally occurs when exogenous insulin is administered (with glucose to prevent hypoglycemia). The plasma K concentration will fall by 0.5-1.5 mmol/L in 15-30 min, and the effect will last for several hours. Alkali therapy with intravenous NaHCO, can also shift K' into cells. This should be reserved for severe hyperkalemia associated with metabolic acidosis. Patients with end-stage renal disease seldom respond to this intervention and may not tolerate the Na" load and resultant volume expansion. When administered parenterally or in nebulized form, beta 2-adrenergic agonists promote cellular uptake of K". The onset of action is 30 min and the effect lasts 2-4 h. Therefore, from the above discussion, the fastest-acting drug in hyperkalemia is calcium gluconate but it does not reduce potassium level and only counteracts the ECG changes induced by K. For reducing the potassium level quickly, the drug is glucose insulin.
